commentText: Yeh draft balanced lagta hai jismein positives aur challenges dono hain. Borrowing aur repayment conditions financial discipline promote karte hain. Auditor certificate bhi ek compliance check deta hai. Holding-subs aur foreign–Indian subsidiary mergers ko simplify karna corporate restructuring ke liye helpful hoga. Lekin iska asli impact monitoring aur enforcement pe depend karega. Agar execution strong hua toh yeh ek progressive change banega.

Mujhe lagta hai yeh draft ek positive step hai. SMEs aur unlisted companies ke liye ab mergers simple ho jaayenge. Borrowing limit 50 crore tak aur no-default clause ek safeguard provide karta hai. Auditor certificate bhi misuse ke chances kam karta hai. Holding-sub companies aur foreign–Indian mergers ke liye yeh ek forward-looking policy hai jo Ease of Doing Business ko promote karegi.

The draft’s intent is fine, but it raises concerns. The ₹50 crore borrowing cap feels excessive and could be exploited through restructuring loans. Heavy reliance on auditor certification is another weak point, considering past lapses in audit independence. Shell companies might misuse simplified holding-subsidiary mergers for tax avoidance. Safeguards like stricter thresholds or regulatory vetting should be included.

The draft seems balanced, offering both advantages and challenges. Borrowing and repayment conditions support discipline, while auditor certification adds compliance. Allowing holding-subsidiary and foreign–Indian subsidiary mergers could ease restructuring. However, the true impact will depend on monitoring and enforcement. If implemented strongly, this draft can be progressive; if weak, it may create loopholes. Overall, cautiously optimistic.

Is draft ki intentions theek hain, lekin kuch problems bhi hain. Borrowing limit ₹50 crore kaafi high hai, aur iska misuse karna easy hai. Auditor certificate par over-dependence risky hai, kyunki pehle bhi auditors fail ho chuke hain. Holding-sub mergers shell companies ke liye ek loophole ban sakte hain. Thoda aur strict safeguards add karne chahiye.

Overall, the draft notification is a positive and practical step. By reducing compliance hurdles for SMEs and unlisted companies, it ensures smoother mergers. The borrowing cap of ₹50 crore and repayment condition safeguard financial discipline. Auditor certification further strengthens transparency. The provisions for holding-subsidiary and foreign–Indian subsidiary mergers streamline restructuring, supporting ease of doing business.
यह संशोधन कॉर्पोरेट जगत के लिए एक दूरदर्शी कदम है। इससे छोटे और अनलिस्टेड कंपनियों को विलय में सुविधा मिलेगी और उनकी लागत कम होगी। इससे पारदर्शिता बढ़ेगी और निवेशक विश्वास मजबूत होगा।

हालांकि मसौदे में सुधार की कोशिश की गई है, लेकिन यह छोटे व्यवसायों पर और अनुपालन का बोझ डालता है। ऑडिटर प्रमाणपत्र की अनिवार्यता से लागत और समय दोनों बढ़ेंगे।

The draft provides flexibility for SMEs and unlisted firms in mergers. The borrowing cap and no-default condition ensure accountability, while the auditor certificate builds trust.
